metadata.title: SF Symbols | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: SF Symbols provides thousands of consistent, highly configurable symbols that integrate seamlessly with the San Francisco system font. The documentation covers rendering modes, weights and scales, design variants, animations, and guidelines for creating custom symbols.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

supportedPlatforms.notes: Full support for all SF Symbols features
Full support for all SF Symbols features
Full support for all SF Symbols features
Full support for all SF Symbols features
Full support for all SF Symbols features
Full support for all SF Symbols features

content.description: SF Symbols provides thousands of consistent, highly configurable symbols that integrate seamlessly with the San Francisco system font, automatically aligning with text in all weights and sizes.
content.availability: Availability of individual symbols and features varies based on the version of the system you're targeting. Symbols and symbol features introduced in a given year aren't available in earlier operating systems.
restrictions: Prohibition against using symbols in app icons
Prohibition against using symbols in logos
Prohibition against any other trademarked use
Prohibition against images that are confusingly similar to SF Symbols in restricted contexts

developerGuidance.reference: Configuring and displaying symbol images in your UI

content.description: SF Symbols provides four rendering modes that give you multiple options when applying color to symbols.

layerSystem.description: SF Symbols organizes a symbol's paths into distinct layers to support rendering modes.

layers.name: Primary
layers.description: The main layer of the symbol
layers.example: In cloud.sun.rain.fill, the primary layer contains the cloud paths

layers.name: Secondary
layers.example: In cloud.sun.rain.fill, the secondary layer contains the sun and rays paths

layers.name: Tertiary
layers.example: In cloud.sun.rain.fill, the tertiary layer contains the raindrop paths

modes.name: Monochrome
modes.description: Applies one color to all layers in a symbol. Within a symbol, paths render in the color you specify or as a transparent shape within a color-filled path.
modes.layerBehavior: All layers receive the same color

modes.name: Hierarchical
modes.description: Applies one color to all layers in a symbol, varying the color's opacity according to each layer's hierarchical level.
modes.layerBehavior: Each layer receives a different opacity of the specified color based on its hierarchical level
modes.useCase: Creating visual depth and hierarchy with a single color

modes.name: Palette
modes.description: Applies two or more colors to a symbol, using one color per layer. Specifying only two colors for a symbol that defines three levels of hierarchy means the secondary and tertiary layers use the same color.
modes.layerBehavior: Each layer can receive a distinct color
modes.useCase: Creating symbols that coordinate with various color schemes

modes.name: Multicolor
modes.description: Applies intrinsic colors to some symbols to enhance meaning.
modes.layerBehavior: Some layers have predefined colors; others can receive custom colors

examples.reason: Reflects the appearance of leaves in the physical world

bestPractices.reason: Ensures symbols automatically adapt to accessibility accommodations and appearance modes like vibrancy and Dark Mode

bestPractices.guideline: Confirm that a symbol's rendering mode works well in every context
bestPractices.reason: Different rendering modes can affect how well people can discern the symbol's details depending on size and contrast with background

bestPractices.guideline: Use the automatic setting to get a symbol's preferred rendering mode
bestPractices.reason: Provides sensible defaults while allowing override where needed

content.description: Gradient rendering generates a smooth linear gradient from a single source color.
features: Renders for symbols of any size
content.recommendation: Gradients look best at larger sizes

fillTypes.name: Gradient fill
fillTypes.description: Smooth linear gradient from source color

content.description: Variable color lets you represent a characteristic that can change over time, like capacity or strength, regardless of rendering mode.
content.mechanism: Applies color to different layers of a symbol as a value reaches different thresholds between zero and 100 percent.

example.behavior: Communicates three different ranges of sound plus the state where there's no sound by mapping layers representing curved wave paths to different ranges of decibel values

states.visualization: First and second wave layers receive color

example.optOutLayers: The speaker path doesn't receive variable color because a speaker doesn't change as the sound level changes

content.flexibility: A symbol can support variable color in any number of layers

bestPractices.guideline: Use variable color to communicate change
bestPractices.reason: Variable color is designed to represent characteristics that vary over time

bestPractices.guideline: Don't use variable color to communicate depth
bestPractices.reason: Use Hierarchical rendering mode instead to convey depth and visual hierarchy

content.description: SF Symbols provides symbols in a wide range of weights and scales to help you create adaptable designs.

weights.correspondence: Each weight corresponds to a weight of the San Francisco system font
weights.purpose: Helps achieve precise weight matching between symbols and adjacent text, while supporting flexibility for different sizes and contexts

scales.definition: Scales are defined relative to the cap height of the San Francisco system font
scales.purpose: Lets you adjust a symbol's emphasis compared to adjacent text, without disrupting the weight matching with text that uses the same point size

content.description: SF Symbols defines several design variants that can help you communicate precise states and actions while maintaining visual consistency and simplicity in your UI.

primaryVariants.name: Outline
primaryVariants.description: The most common variant. Has no solid areas, resembling the appearance of text.
useCases: Places where you display a symbol alongside text

primaryVariants.name: Fill
primaryVariants.description: Areas within some shapes are solid. Gives a symbol more visual emphasis.
useCases: Places where you use an accent color to communicate selection

additionalVariants.name: Slash
additionalVariants.description: A diagonal line through the symbol
additionalVariants.useCase: Show that an item or action is unavailable

content.combinations: Enclosed and slash variants can combine with outline or fill variants

localizationVariants.description: SF Symbols provides many variants for specific languages and writing systems.
localizationVariants.behavior: Language- and script-specific variants adapt automatically when the device language changes

automaticVariantSelection.description: In many cases, the view that displays a symbol determines whether to use outline or fill, so you don't have to specify a variant.

content.description: SF Symbols provides a collection of expressive, configurable animations that enhance your interface and add vitality to your app. Symbol animations help communicate ideas, provide feedback in response to people's actions, and signal changes in status or ongoing activities.

compatibility.symbols: All SF Symbols in the library

modes: Run indefinitely, repeating until a condition is met

animationTypes.name: Appear
animationTypes.description: Causes a symbol to gradually emerge into view.
animationTypes.behavior: Symbol fades in and/or scales up into visibility
animationTypes.useCase: Introducing a symbol into the interface

animationTypes.name: Disappear
animationTypes.description: Causes a symbol to gradually recede out of view.
animationTypes.behavior: Symbol fades out and/or scales down out of visibility
animationTypes.useCase: Removing a symbol from the interface

animationTypes.name: Bounce
animationTypes.description: Briefly scales a symbol with an elastic-like movement that goes either up or down and then returns to the symbol's initial state.
animationTypes.behavior: Symbol scales with spring-like motion and returns to original state
animationTypes.useCase: Communicate that an action occurred or needs to take place

animationTypes.name: Scale
animationTypes.description: Changes the size of a symbol, increasing or decreasing its scale.
animationTypes.behavior: Symbol changes size and maintains new scale until changed or effect removed
useCases: Draw people's attention to a selected item
Feedback when people choose a symbol

animationTypes.name: Pulse
animationTypes.description: Varies the opacity of a symbol over time.
animationTypes.behavior: Automatically pulses only layers annotated to pulse, or optionally all layers
animationTypes.useCase: Communicate ongoing activity until a condition is met

animationTypes.name: Variable Color
animationTypes.description: Incrementally varies the opacity of layers within a symbol.

modes.name: Cumulative
modes.behavior: Color changes persist for each layer until the animation cycle is complete

modes.name: Iterative
modes.behavior: Color changes occur one layer at a time

customizations: Autoreverse (reverse animation to starting point and replay)
Hide inactive layers (rather than reduce opacity)

loopTypes.name: Open loop
loopTypes.description: Layers arranged linearly where start and end points don't meet

loopTypes.name: Closed loop
loopTypes.description: Layers follow a complete shape where start and end points meet (like circular progress indicators)

useCases: Ongoing activity such as playback, connecting, or broadcasting

animationTypes.name: Replace
animationTypes.description: Replaces one symbol with another. Works between arbitrary symbols and across all weights and rendering modes.

configurations.name: Down-up
configurations.behavior: Outgoing symbol scales down, incoming symbol scales up

configurations.name: Up-up
configurations.behavior: Both outgoing and incoming symbols scale up
configurations.meaning: Change in state with sense of forward progression

configurations.name: Off-up
configurations.behavior: Outgoing symbol hides immediately, incoming symbol scales up
configurations.meaning: State change emphasizing the next available state or action

animationTypes.name: Magic Replace
animationTypes.description: Performs a smart transition between two symbols with related shapes.
behaviors: Slashes can draw on and off
Badges can be replaced independently of base symbol

fallback.customization: Can choose custom direction for fallback animation

animationTypes.name: Wiggle
animationTypes.description: Moves the symbol back and forth along a directional axis.
useCases: Highlight a change or call to action that might be overlooked
Add dynamic emphasis to an interaction
Reinforce what the symbol represents (e.g., arrow pointing in direction)

animationTypes.name: Breathe
animationTypes.description: Smoothly increases and decreases the presence of a symbol, giving it a living quality.
animationTypes.comparison: Similar to pulse, but pulse animates opacity alone while breathe changes both opacity and size
useCases: Signal ongoing activity like recording session

animationTypes.name: Rotate
animationTypes.description: Rotates the symbol to act as a visual indicator or imitate an object's behavior in the real world.

behaviors.example: Desk fan symbol spins only the fan blades

animationTypes.useCase: Confirm that a task is in progress and working as expected

animationTypes.name: Draw On / Draw Off
animationTypes.description: Draws the symbol along a path through a set of guide points.
layerModes: Draw each layer one at a time

bestPractices.reason: Too many animations can overwhelm an interface and distract people

bestPractices.guideline: Make sure that animations serve a clear purpose in communicating a symbol's intent
bestPractices.reason: Each animation type has discrete movement that communicates certain actions or elicits certain responses

bestPractices.guideline: Use symbol animations to communicate information more efficiently
bestPractices.reason: Animations provide visual feedback and can present complex information simply without taking up visual space

bestPractices.guideline: Consider your app's tone when adding animations
bestPractices.reason: Animation should align with brand identity and app's overall style and tone

content.description: If you need a symbol that SF Symbols doesn't provide, you can create your own by exporting a template for a similar symbol and modifying it with a vector-editing tool.
content.developerReference: Creating custom symbol images for your app

restrictions.important: SF Symbols includes copyrighted symbols that depict Apple products and features. You can display these symbols in your app, but you can't customize them.
restrictions.identification: SF Symbols app badges non-customizable symbols with an Info icon

annotating.description: Using a process called annotating, you can assign a specific color or hierarchical level to each layer in a custom symbol.
annotating.flexibility: Can use different rendering modes in each instance of the symbol in your app

designGuidelines.guideline: Use the template as a guide
designGuidelines.details: Create a custom symbol consistent with system symbols in level of detail, optical weight, alignment, position, and perspective

designGuidelines.guideline: Design a symbol that is simple
designGuidelines.reason: Maintains consistency with SF Symbols design language

designGuidelines.guideline: Design a symbol that is recognizable
designGuidelines.reason: Users should quickly understand the symbol's meaning

designGuidelines.guideline: Design a symbol that is inclusive
designGuidelines.reason: Symbols should be accessible and culturally appropriate

designGuidelines.guideline: Design a symbol that is directly related to the action or content it represents

margins.guideline: Assign negative side margins to your custom symbol if necessary
margins.purpose: Aid optical horizontal alignment when a symbol contains a badge or other elements that increase its width
margins.example: Help horizontally align a stack of folder symbols, some of which include a badge

animations.guideline: Optimize layers to use animations with custom symbols
requirements: Annotate layers in SF Symbols app for by-layer animation
Z-order determines color application order for variable color symbols
Can animate by layer groups for related layers to move together

testing.reason: Shapes and paths might not appear as expected when layers are in motion

drawingTechnique.guideline: Consider drawing custom symbols with whole shapes
drawingTechnique.example: A symbol like person.2.fill doesn't need a cutout for the person on the left. Draw the full shape and add an offset path for the gap.
drawingTechnique.method: Annotate offset path as erase layer to render as desired
drawingTechnique.benefit: Preserves additional layer information for better animation performance

variants.guideline: Avoid making custom symbols that include common variants such as enclosures or badges
variants.reason: SF Symbols app offers a component library for creating variants
variants.benefit: Maintains design consistency with included SF Symbols

accessibility.guideline: Provide alternative text labels for custom symbols
accessibility.purpose: Let VoiceOver describe visible UI and content
accessibility.benefit: Makes navigation easier for people with visual disabilities

prohibitions.guideline: Don't design replicas of Apple products
Don't customize symbols representing Apple features or products
prohibitions.reason: These are restricted by SF Symbols

content.note: No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.
content.implication: SF Symbols guidelines apply uniformly across all Apple platforms

downloads.name: SF Symbols App
downloads.description: Download the app to browse the full set of symbols

developerDocumentation.title: Configuring and displaying symbol images in your UI
Creating custom symbol images for your app

changes: Updated with guidance for Draw animations in SF Symbols 7
Updated with guidance for gradient rendering in SF Symbols 7
Updated with guidance for new animations and features of SF Symbols 6
Added a new section on animations
Included animation guidance for custom symbols
Added a new section on variable color
Removed instructions on creating custom symbol paths, exporting templates, and layering paths, deferring to developer articles

hierarchical.behavior: Single color with varying opacity per layer

implementationExamples.notes: Examples are illustrative; refer to official Apple documentation for complete API usage
